bestBHT.bht: Be prepared and ready at all times for the return of Christ, for it is our duty and the right of Christ to expect us to be sober, vigilant, and always waiting for his coming. Our journey in this world is filled with darkness, but we are guided by the torch of heavenly doctrine. When Christ descends from heaven, all those who have believed and remained faithful will joyfully and willingly meet him. Let us stay in a state of readiness, awaiting the return of Christ, the bridegroom of the church.

Henry Alford: 36.] ye yourselves, i.e. your whole conduct and demeanour.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Return from the wedding—not come to it, as in the parable of the virgins.
Both [the parable of the virgins and preparedness for Christ's coming] have their spiritual significance.
Preparedness for Christ's coming is the prominent idea.
Marvin Vincent: The verb [αναλυση] means, originally, to unloose: so of vessels, to unloose their moorings and go to sea.
This is its sense in the only other passage where it occurs, Philippians 1:23, 'having a desire to depart, or break up; the metaphor being drawn from breaking up an encampment.'
The rendering return is a kind of inference from this: when he shall leave the wedding and return.
John Calvin: It would be improper for us to give way to indolent repose.

If a mortal man looks upon it as a duty which his servants owe him, that, at whatever hour he returns home, they shall be prepared to receive him, how much more has he a right to demand from his followers that they shall be sober and vigilant, and always wait for his coming?
Our journey must be performed amidst the thick darkness of the world, and yet we are protected from the risk of going astray, while the torch of heavenly doctrine goes before us.
Philip Schaff: When he will return from the marriage feast. The main thought is simply that He is away at a feast, and expected to return."
In the parable of the Ten Virgins (Matthew 25:1-13), the return of the Bridegroom is the main thought.
Straightway open unto him. Because they are ready, and have nothing to hide.
Archibald T. Robertson: The figure is breaking up a camp or loosening the mooring of a ship, to depart."
Genitive absolute of the aorist active participle without αυτου and in spite of αυτο (dative) being used after ανοιξωσιν (first aorist active subjunctive of ανοιγω).
John Gill: so be ye in a readiness, waiting for the coming of Christ, the bridegroom of the church
when Christ has, by the preaching of the Gospel, and the power of his grace, espoused all his elect, he will descend from heaven, and take them to himself
those who have believed in Christ, and have been faithful to his cause and interest...shall be ready to obey the summons with the greatest cheerfulness, and meet him with the utmost pleasure.

bhtAttempts.bht: Be prepared and ready at all times for the return of Christ, just as servants must be prepared to receive their master when he returns home from a feast. Our journey in this world is filled with darkness, but we are guided by the torch of heavenly doctrine. We must not give in to laziness or complacency, for it is our duty and the right of Christ to expect us to be sober, vigilant, and always waiting for his coming. When he descends from heaven, all those who have believed and remained faithful to him will joyfully and willingly meet him. So let us stay in a state of readiness, eagerly awaiting the coming of Christ, the bridegroom of the church.
